entry.title: Needfinding Introduction
entry.content:
Reading note of a Needfinding book, which I cannot find its author.

Introduction

Leaders in any organization were those people who found important new problems to work on, not necessarily those who ultimately solved the problems. The greatest impact that designers could have on product development, then, was at the earliest stages of product definition.

Note: Find what to solve is always more important than solve the specific problem. In a technical sense, this means you have a big picture on what you are working. This provides you with guidance. But on the other side, you have to have the enough skillset to be able to know how you can solve the problems.

Needfinding is the act of discovering people’s explicit and implicit needs so that designers can create apppropriate solutions.

Needfinding has come to include elements of design planning: providing guidance and strategies for what a successful solution might be.

Needfinding has thus evolved into a methodology that’s a hybrid of both design research and design planning. That hybridity is one of Needfinding’s core strenths.

Question: what does design research and design planning means?

Core Principles of Needfinding

  • Look for needs, not solutions.
  • Make research and design seamless.
  • Spend time in the participants’ world.
  • Look beyond the immediately solvable problem
  • Let the participants set the agenda
  • Collect eclectic forms of data
  • Make findings tangible and prescriptive
  • Iterate to refine the findings.

entry.title: Playbook for Strategic Foresight and Innovation Reading Notes Series -- Chapter Five
entry.content:
This chapter is about connecting your idea generated from previous work to market, to reality, through which you find lingering assumptions, critical areas untouched and converge your ideas.

Four methods are provided.

White Spots

White spots means unexplored market space. In my view, the point of this method is to give you a start point – find two most critical demision of you context map, draw a 2X2 matrix based on them, fill what the market already have, what are expected to have and what are imagined to have but cannot. Then you find the missing point of the market.

{% img center /images/white_spots.png ‘White Spots Illustration’ ‘White Spots Illustration’ %}

The process gives a hint to begin.

Paper Mockup

This one is similar to the future telling method. However, the latter focus on the function you want to have by testing in senario with imagination. This one is more about bring a rought physical prototype with the function you want by the fastest way.

To try it on real scenario, on real people, you get the realization of your concept and feedback about your idea.

{% img center /images/paper_mockup.png ‘Paper Mockup Illustration’ ‘Paper Mockup Illustration’ %}

Some nice questions prompt thoughts:

  • Which aspects of your prototype did the audience focus on? Why?

  • Which elements of your idea did your team leave out of your prototype? Why?

  • Which part of the prototype exist today, and which parts need to be built? Which pieces cannot exist today?

  • How should you document and capture the lessons from building and presenting this prototype?

Some advice:

  • Deliberately deep your design rough, so that it looks incomplete and thus invites constructive feedback from others.

Dark horse prototype

At the phase of generating your team’s ideas, there are ones being discarded. However, it happens that the greatest ideas are among the ones that are discarded. So find one of them and do a prototype could give your a valuable lesson.

{% img center /images/dark_horse.png ‘Dark Horse Illustration’ ‘Dark Horse Illustration’ %}

Change Path

This part is about planning – to find a start point to get you moved and to identify the milestones in the process of achieving your idea.

Simply knowing what to do tomorrow helps break inertia. Ask yourself, what am I going to do on Monday? Who am I going to call?

{% img center /images/change_path.png ‘Change Path Illustration’ ‘Change Path Illustration’ %}

Stop

This series stops here. There are still two chapters left but they are less relevant to what I am doing right now, so I decide not to read them for the time being.

entry.title: Playbook for Strategic Foresight and Innovation Reading Notes Series -- Chapter Four
entry.content:
The perspective chapter is about knowing what has been done, what works and what not, and why some works and some not.

This chapter stops discovering the past but focus on the future. What opportunities lie on in the future.

The overall idea of this chapter is clear. Three methods are provided.

Generational Arcs

Generational Arcs try to catch the big picture of the target people – the age versus population distribution. This is a rough mathematical model to estimate the current state and how will the state shift in the future.

{% img center /images/generational_arc.png “Generational Arcs Illustration” “Generational Arcs Illustration” %}

From the modeling result, we may get a sense of the amount of our target peole and how it would change in the future.

Future User

This method have finer granunity. It tries to summarize the typical characteritics and the change may happen in the future of one group of people in the target population – there may be more than one persona to represent different groups in the Generational Arcs.

{% img center /images/future_user.png “Future User Illustration” “Future User Illustration” %}

From the characteritics found, we could have a more concrete person, in other word, persona, to work on.

Future Telling

And future telling focus not on the characteritics but on the scenario. In what scenario would the user in now and in the future?

{% img center /images/future_telling.png “Future Telling Illustration” “Future Telling Illustration” %}

This is like the procedural programming. You first go the program in your mind once before getting it coded. But the Future Telling should be more physical – a mock scenario is expected to be done.

From the insight found from the mock scenario, what the product will be like would become more concrete.

entry.title: Playbook for Strategic Foresight and Innovation Reading Notes Series -- Chapter Three, Perspective
entry.content:
This chapter is about knowing the background of your research topic. There are some inner laws in the process of design. This chapter provides a clear definition between different phases of doing background reseach, or in other word, benchmarking.

Three methods are provided.

Context Map

Capture what plays an important role in the problem or idea you want to deal with. It emphasizes on the quantity of the factors influencing the problem. It says eight factor, no more to make the problem too complex or no less to capture enough dimensions.

Some notes about drawing the context map. Essentially, it should be no difference from listing a list of factors. However, it is the graph structure that matters. So it would be helpful to make sure the map is big enough for taking notes for the team members.

{% img center /images/context_map.png “Context Map Illustration” “Context Map Illustration” %}

Progression Curves & Janus Cones

The two methods are all about get the backgound of your problem from a perspective involving time.

At first, the difference between Progression Curves and Janus Cones confuses me.

Context Map emphasizes on factors. This method emphasizes on efforts already put in the problem, the pattern of events happened, and how these events have led to its current state.

{% img center /images/progression_curves.png “Progression Curves Illustration” “Progression Curves Illustration” %}

But, Janus Cones also emphasizes on events. The book says, Janus Cones is to discern a possible pattern of relationships among many related(and even unrelated) events. Progression Curves also talks about events.

{% img center /images/janus_cones.png “Janus Cones Illustration” “Janus Cones Illustration” %}

From the words talking about Progression Curves, “you can draw a progression curve for each demision of your context map”, I think Janus Cones is the combination of a bunble of Progression Curves, and it emphasizes on the relation between event that are in different progression curves.

Some comments

In my view, those methods are also very useful for the academic research life I am going to pursue. Hope could try it out in the future.

entry.title: Playbook for Strategic Foresight and Innovation Reading Notes Series -- Chapter Two
entry.content:
This chapter is a should-read-twice chapter. Similar to previous chapter, this chapter tries to provides a overview for reader. However, it is more specific. It breaks the innovation process down and dicuss them separately.

Actually, this is the second time that I have read this chapter – not the should-read-twice meaning what I meant just now. At the first time, the reading was not mandatory, so I did not persist reading all the book. And for the second time, I completely forget what I learnt at the first time. This chapter is hard to comprehend without action.

Now, the reading notes begin.

Why a playbook

At the beginning, the author stresses the role of this book – playbook.

A playbook is a notebook containing the descriptions and diagrams of all the possible plays and strategies used by a team.

This book is about coaching you and your teammates. And it is hard, like everything else that is great.

Some definitions

Then the author makes clear some definitions to make sure readers understand two important basic concept of this playbook.

Strategic Foresight

Acknowledge the ambiguity of the future. Use methods to get a view the future and influence it.

Innovation

This is what everyone knows, finding, building and taking a new idea into the marketplace.

Radical Innovation

The difference between Innovation and Radical Innovation is Radical Innovation create huge ideas which have huge impact.

Break down the innovation process

Then beginning with the start of the innovation process, the author breaks it down and discuss:

  1. What type of growth do we seek, which determines what kinds of ideas we want to think of.
  2. For an idea, where do we get our inspiration?
  3. The roles people play when the innovation process starts.
  4. The influence the contexts of industries will bring to the innovation process.

Learning process

After the breakdown of the innovation process, the author provides guide about how to learn and use the method provided in this playbook.

Finish

As I have written, this is a should-read-twice chapter. Or more precise, this is learning instructions. When finishing reading this book and going to apply the methods, go back and check the advice offered by the author.

There are 10 valuable advices at the end of this chapter.
